_accidents.CI_OtherType: Installation of Float at hot gas line low point and addition of 17 relief valves to prevent over-pressure

_exec_summary.SummaryText: g employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

er 14, 2020 a leak was caused by an approximate 1.5” tear in the fan coil unit in one of the penthouses. This unit was originally a freezer unit and is now a cooler unit. The tenants (both Dollar General employees and employees from TK Classics in the adjacent suite) evacuated the building. The refrigeration contractor was contacted and the system was shut down and the release was stopped. The West Sacramento Fire Department was notified and responded to the facility. The coil was completely decommissioned and blocked off. An ICM Float at the hot gas line low point and 17 relief valves were added to prevent over-pressure. Approximately 12,000 pounds of ammonia was released as found by the charge receipts from the following months.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Dollar General has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community. The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure. Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP. In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor and the fire department for assistance as necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
A Process Hazard Analysis study has been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system. This study has resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility. The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment. Dollar General has implemented several action items. In addition, the facility plans to continue providin

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Dollar General is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities. This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility. For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system. Dollar General has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition. Only trained refrigeration contractors are permitted to perform system operations and maintenance. All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility. In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur. At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The Dollar General facility located at 3771 Channel Drive, Suite 150 in West Sacramento, California. Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage and distribution of grocery products. The system uses a maximum of 14,010 pounds of ammonia. A description of how the process operates is presented below:

Liquid ammonia in the high pressure receiver is fed to the recirculators. The recirculators pump liquid to the evaporators. At the evaporators, air is drawn over the coils by the fans. The ammonia flowing inside the coils is partially vaporized as it absorbs heat from the product and surrounding air. The partially vaporized ammonia is returned to the respective recirculator, where the liquid settles at the bottom of the vessel, while the vapor rises to the top. The vapor in the vessel is pulled off by the compressors. The compressed vapor is discharged to the condensers.
